Award.AwardTitle: Microfluidic Single-Cell Melting Curve Analysis for Broad-Scale Detection of Microbial Organisms

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
Despite considerable progress made in developing microfluidic
technologies for biological analysis, including droplet microfluidics to enable scalable partitioning of fluid
into tiny compartments for single cell analysis, transforming the technology into practical applications are
still hindered by 1) inadequate macro-to-micro interface to cope with large volume biological samples
containing complex matrix; 2) complicated post-PCR processing for multiplexed, broad-scale genotypic
analysis; and 3) insufficient progress toward system integration.
In this project, we plan to develop a fully integrated micro total analysis system (��TAS) for high
throughput broad-scale microbial detection and genotypic identification from a mixed population at single
cell resolution. Our novel platform will incorporate a microfluidic droplet generator to encapsulate single
bacterial cells into a large quantity of pL-sized droplets where the cells are lysed and enzymatic reactions
take place to facilitate high throughput single cell PCR amplification. For broad-scale bacterial detection
and species identification, we will incorporate a previously validated 16S rRNA PCR assay coupled with
high resolution melt analysis (HRMA) for amplicon sequence analysis. This platform will not only provide
highly accurate quantification of bacterial load, but the incorporation of HRMA at the single cell level
permits both broad-scale species identification, as well as unprecedented resolution in measuring relative
abundance of bacterial species present in a mixed population.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The major goal of this project was to develop a microfluidic-enhanced molecular diagnostic platform that is able to carry out sample processing, PCR amplification, and multiplexed detection of microbial organisms via high-resolution melt curve analysis (HRM). Throughout the project period, we overcame several technical challenges and accomplished all of the major tasks we proposed. We developed HRM assays for multiplexed detection, microfluidic devices for digital detection, and optical instrumentation and control programs for high-sensitivity fluorescence detection and high resolution melt analysis.   We developed a droplet manipulation scheme on a credit card-sized device that facilitates all of the necessary fluidic operations (such as liquid metering, separation, and mixing) needed to carry out integrated sample processing, PCR, and genetic detection of microbial organisms. In order to facilitate broad-scale and multiplex detection via HRM, we developed a support vector machine learning algorithm (SVM) that enables automated and reliable identification of DNA sequence variants. We further set out to maximize the differentiating ability of HRM+SVM for a single genetic locus by incorporating longer amplicons harboring more sequence information. Using the hypervariable bacterial 16S rDNA gene (16S) as a model system, we showed that long amplicons yield more complex and distinguishable HRM curve shapes than short amplicons. HRM using broad-based bacterial 16S rRNA gene primers demonstrated universal, single cell detection of bacterial pathogens, even in the presence of larger amounts of contaminating bacteria. We demonstrated the feasibility and utility of HRM through detection of bacteria associated with polymicrobial blood infection and through detection of microRNAs associated with host response to infection. We also developed a droplet microchip and an instrument for performing chip-based HRM detection of DNA.

The proposed project has contributed to the practice of health care. The microfluidic platform holds promise for revealing the differences among individual cells that compose a group. The new capability has broad implications, from gaining a fundamental understanding of human pathology to developing new medical treatments for disease states. In microbiology, application of our innovative platform may improve the way infectious disease is understood, diagnosed, and managed.

Our project also provided educational opportunities for young students. Our team collaborated with the Women in the Science and Engineering (WISE) Program to provide young women with science and engineering mentoring and research experience with a goal to foster a new generation of women scientists and engineers. Through the WISE program, we mentored a student from Paul Laurence Dunbar High School and a student from Garrison Forest High School. We also participated in mentoring Baltimore city school children through STEM Achievement in Baltimore Elementary Schools (SABES). In particular, we worked with a third grade class at Highlandtown #237 Elementary School, located in the Highlandtown neighborhood of Baltimore. As afterschool volunteers, we visited with the class for approximately two hours once a week, and we helped the teacher deliver STEM-themed lessons with many hands-on activities.
